cdata.constitutionalAuthorityStatementText: [Congressional Record Volume 169, Number 127 (Monday, July 24, 2023)][House]From the Congressional Record Online through the Government Publishing Office [www.gpo.gov]By Ms. NORTON:H.R. 4834.Congress has the power to enact this legislation pursuantto the following:clause 17 of section 8 of article I of the ConstitutionThe single subject of this legislation is:This bill would give the District of Columbia the authorityto appoint all members of the D.C. Zoning Commission.[Page H3896]

item.text: Referred to the House Committee on Oversight and Accountability.
Sponsor introductory remarks on measure. (CR E706)

cdata.text:
District of Columbia Zoning Commission Home Rule Act

This bill modifies the composition of the District of Columbia Zoning Commission to require the commission to consist of only three mayoral appointees. Currently, the commission consists of five individuals: three mayoral appointees, the Architect of the Capitol, and the Director of the National Park Service. The bill removes the Architect of the Capitol and the Director of the National Park Service from the commission.

bill.title: District of Columbia Zoning Commission Home Rule Act

item.title: District of Columbia Zoning Commission Home Rule Act
District of Columbia Zoning Commission Home Rule Act
To revise the composition of the Zoning Commission for the District of Columbia so that the Commission will consist solely of members appointed by the government of the District of Columbia.

latestAction.text: Referred to the House Committee on Oversight and Accountability.

dublinCore.dc:rights: Pursuant to Title 17 Section 105 of the United States Code, this file is not subject to copyright protection and is in the public domain.
dublinCore.dc:contributor: Congressional Research Service, Library of Congress
dublinCore.dc:description: This file contains bill summaries and statuses for federal legislation. A bill summary describes the most significant provisions of a piece of legislation and details the effects the legislative text may have on current law and federal programs. Bill summaries are authored by the Congressional Research Service (CRS) of the Library of Congress. As stated in Public Law 91-510 (2 USC 166 (d)(6)), one of the duties of CRS is "to prepare summaries and digests of bills and resolutions of a public general nature introduced in the Senate or House of Representatives". For more information, refer to the User Guide that accompanies this file.
